for each of the four cells in the block (i,j), (i,j+1), (i+1,j), (i+1,j+1):

But if the code breaks in j=0 (i=0), then for the next i=1 loop, the j starts again at 0. But black and white are still whatever they were after breaking. Because each 2x2 block should be counted independently.

Thus, the original code has a bug. The variables black and white should be reset to 0 at the start of each i and j iteration.

reset black and white to 0.

check the four cells.

Thus, in the Python code, the variables are initialized once, and not reset per block. So the code is wrong.

Therefore, when translating to C, this error should be fixed. The correct code would reset black and white to 0 at the start of each j iteration.

So in C, inside the i and j loops, before processing the four cells, black and white should be set to 0.

So the correct steps for each block:

- reset black and white to 0.

- check each of the four cells, incrementing black or white.

- check the condition.

for i from 0 to 2:

    for j from 0 to 2:

        black = 0;

        white = 0;

So this would fix the bug.

So in the original Python code, the variables black and white are not reset at the start of each j loop. Thus, the code is incorrect, and the C translation should correct that.

Therefore, the correct approach is to move the reset of black and white to the start of each j loop.

So in the Python code, the line 'black=0' and 'white=0' are at the end of the j loop. But if the code breaks due to the condition being met, those variables are not reset. So when the next j loop starts (for the next i), the variables are not reset, leading to incorrect counts.

Thus, to fix this, in the C code, we should set black and white to 0 at the start of each j loop iteration.

So, the C code would be:

#include <stdio.h>

int main() {

    char t[4][5];
    for (int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
        scanf("%s", t[i]);
    }

    int correct = 0;

    for (int i = 0; i < 3; i++) {
        for (int j = 0; j < 3; j++) {
            int black = 0, white = 0;

            if (t[i][j] == '#') black++;
            else white++;

            if (t[i][j+1] == '#') black++;
            else white++;

            if (t[i+1][j] == '#') black++;
            else white++;

            if (t[i+1][j+1] == '#') black++;
            else white++;

            if (black == 0 || black == 3 || black ==4 || white ==0 || white ==3 || white ==4) {
                correct = 1;
                break;
            }
        }
        if (correct) break;
    }

    printf("%s\n", correct ? "YES" : "NO");

    return 0;
}

Wait, but in the original Python code, after processing each j, if not breaking, it resets black and white. But in reality, for each j, the code should process a new block, so the reset is unnecessary if they are initialized at the start of the j loop.

Thus, the C code initializes black and white to 0 at the start of each j iteration, which is correct.

Additionally, in the original Python code, after breaking out of the j loop (when correct is 1), the code continues to the next i. So to optimize, in C, once correct is set to 1, we can break out of the i loop as well. Thus, adding a check after the inner loop to break the outer loop if correct is 1.

This is done in the C code above with 'if (correct) break;' after the inner j loop.

So this makes the code more efficient, but also correct. Because once a correct block is found, there's no need to check further.

Thus, the translated C code should correctly replicate the intended logic, with the necessary corrections for the reset of black and white.

Another thing to consider is how input is read. In Python, input().split() would read a line and split into characters. In C, using scanf("%s", t[i]) reads a string (without whitespace). So as long as each input line is exactly 4 characters (without any leading or trailing spaces), this will work.

Thus, the code reads four lines of four characters each, then checks each 2x2 block. If any block has all four same, three same and one different, then output YES.

This should correctly replicate the Python code's intended functionality, but with the necessary fixes to the variable initialization.
